projects.title: Uitzending Niger
projects.description:
Commander ACOTA mission Niger/ Senior National Respresentative
Niger, Niamey and Ouallam
			
Work environment:
The ACOTA program (African Contingency Operations Training and Assistance) is developed and funded by the US Department of State in order to increase the capabilities of African military forces in areas such as human rights, interaction with civil society, international law, military staff skills, and small unit operations, specifically for peace keeping and peace support missions. Although the US Army provides a number of instructors/ trainers, ACOTA has been largely outsourced to private military companies (PMCs). The Netherlands support the program through the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (financial aid) and the Ministry of Defence (instructors/ trainers).

Responsibilities:
The ACOTA program in Niger consisted of a 10 week training for a Niger battalion prior to their deployment in Mali (MINUSMA mission). The Royal Netherlands Army supported the training with 1 officer and 3 non-commisioned officers.
As the senior national respresentative (SNR) I was responsible for the coordination between “Engility” (the PMC responsible for the ACOTA program in Niger), the Dutch personnel and the Dutch Ministry of Defence. 
As a trainer I was responsible for training the company grade officers in troop leading procedures and training the companies in mounted operations.
My secondary job as SNR was to provide the MIVD (Dutch Military Intelligence and Security Service) with information and intelligence as the national intelligence point of contact.

profile_positions.description:
Deputy Commander, Combat Engineer School

Work environment:
As a major I am part of the staff of the Combat Engineer School and responsible
for the daily management of the school. The school is divided in 5 subunits
(instruction platoons): basic engineer training for cadre, advanced training
(including intermediate staff training, intelligence and reconnaissance, heavy
engineer equipment), DEMS (demolition, explosives, mines and military search) and camouflage and deception.
With fluctuating student numbers, it is my job to make sure that the instruction platoons remain able to do their jobs. That means I am pro-actively on the lookout for any problems, and making sure the right people get to the table to solve these problems as early as possible.
Responsibilities
-Current and future operations and planning.
-’Crisis’ response.
-Finances (training budgets).
-Informally coach the younger officers.

profile_positions.description:
Work environment: 
After skydive and wind tunnel coaching for a couple of years I have decided to make it official and start my own coaching company. 

Responsibilities
-general management
-accountancy and invoicing
-planning and organizing skydiving events
-coaching and load organizing for freeflyers
-windtunnel coaching for beginning and intermediate freeflyers
-contact with (potential) sponsors for events

-Gold medal (Dutch nationals, freefly) with Protocol as cameraman in 2012 and as performer in 2013 and 2014
-Gold medal (Dutch nationals, freefly) with Blueshift as cameraman in 2016 and as performer in 2018
-Gold medal (Dutch Indoor Skydiving Championship, dynamic 2-way int.) with NoBe 2017
-Dutch head-up record holder (12-way, 2016)
-European head-up record holder (43-way, 2017)
-Official freefly coach/ examiner

His first contact with parachuting was in 2002 when he signed up for a 5 jump “static line” course on the Military Academy. In despite of the tremendous thrill, the urge to continue skydiving did not stick.
After completing two missions in Afghanistan with the airborne forces (red berets) he decided to take his (military) parachuting adventure to the next level by participating in an (civil) AFF- course (Accelerated Free Fall) in 2010. Free falling, or skydiving, was far more to his like and since completing the AFF- course he can be found at a dropzone almost every weekend!

In 2012 Bennie completed the Dutch equivalent of USPA’s “instructor static line”, meaning that he is allowed to give both initial skydiving courses and additional advanced training to students. Besides giving instruction to students, Bennie is also coaching beginning and intermediate freeflyers.

Since July 2015 Bennie got his official ToraTora/KNVvL freefly coach rating, and since 2018 he is a coach examiner.

Bennie made 2500+ jumps and has 140+ hours of wind tunnel time.

profile_positions.description:
Work environment: 
My work at the Land Training Center is twofold. On the one hand I assist infantry related courses by teaching (deputy) company commanders and (company) sergeant-majors all they need to know about combat engineers, for both airborne and mechanized units. As one of the few engineer officers, I am often asked to advice in engineer related operations by the other sections of the Land Training Center, as well as I am asked to review field manuals (e.g. battlegroup and taskforce level). 
On the other hand, I serve as an observer-trainer-evaluator (OTE) for the engineer officers during field and staff training exercises. Normally at company level, with the engineer advisor being a lieutenant (platoon commander) or his deputy in the rank of first sergeant. But with two vacancies at battalion level OTE I am also tasked to observe, train and evaluate engineer officers at battalion level. At the battalion level, the engineer advisor has the rank of major (company commander), assisted by a very experienced NCO in the rank of sergeant-major. These ranks require a very different approach than the lower ranking lieutenants.

Responsibilities
-teaching both mechanized and airborne officers and NCOs how to use their attached engineer units/advisor
-Observe, train and evaluate engineer officers and NCOs during field and staff training exercises at (infantry) company and battalion level
-Informally coach the younger officers.

profile_positions.description:
Omgeving:
11 Geniecompagnie heeft tot doel om de 11e Luchtmobiele Brigade te steunen in mobiliteit, contra-mobiliteit, bescherming en algemene genietaken (bijv. brugverkenningen). De 11e Luchtmobiele brigade treedt op in zeer zware fysieke en mentale omstandigheden en doorgaans achter de vijandelijke linies (bijvoorbeeld als parachutist). Hiervoor is vereist dat eenieder de rode baret haalt, een zeer zware opleiding die slechts een op de drie succesvol afrondt.

Verantwoordelijkheden:
Als luitenant logistiek was ik verantwoordelijk voor alle logistieke zaken (in de brede zin van het woord) voor 11 Geniecompagnie (125 man): eten en drinken (tijdens oefeningen), veldversterkingsmiddelen (bijv. tenten of prikkeldraad), brandstof, munitie. 
Maar ook vervoer, strategische verplaatsingen, geneeskundige afvoer en herstel- en bergingssteun.
Ook de administratieve afhandeling (beheer) van het aanvragen van nieuwe en/ of vervangende onderdelen en verbruiksartikelen viel onder mijn verantwoordelijkheid.
Om de genoemde taken uit te voeren stuurde ik het logistieke peloton aan. 
Ik had eveneens als taak om de commandant te adviseren over bovengenoemde zaken en hem te assisteren in zijn besluitvormingsproces.

Daarnaast was ik commandant van het stafpeloton. Dit hield met name in dat ik administratief verantwoordelijk was voor het stafpeloton (voor medewerkers staf: zie functie plaatsvervangend commandant).
